intro: Orobanche nebrodensis, commonly known as the Nebrodensis broomrape, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its lack of leaves and its distinctive, showy, often yellow or red flowers. The plant typically grows in Mediterranean regions and is often found parasitizing members of the Leguminosae family. Its life cycle involves germinating in response to chemical signals released by host roots, after which it attaches to the host and derives all its nutrients from it. Due to its parasitic nature, it can significantly impact the growth and yield of its host plants.
